I've been thinking about internet terminology, recently I mentioned a word that used to be super common several years ago, but someone had to look up in today's world https://chat.zulip.org/#narrow/stream/138-user-community/topic/there.20can.20be.20only.20one.20(topic.20name).

One of the phrases that bothers me is "Private message" and the shorthand: PM.
I believe today's world has replaced these with the words "Direct message" and the shorthand: DM.

I believe usage of "PM" comes from IRC and forums and would look more and more off as trends shift. I'm not sure where "DM" comes from but Slack, twitter and discord use the term direct.

Changing would probably be painful. How does everyone else feel about this?

I think it's too painful to change. We should possibly update our glossary to have a little section at the top mapping some names:

  • DM -> PM
  • channel -> stream
Yeah, "Direct Message" is terminology from Twitter that other products seems to be standardizing on, probably because ~everyone has used Twitter.
I actually don't think it's be particularly painful to change that if we wanted to.

$ git grep -i 'private message'  |grep -v locale | wc
    253    2193   25691
So I'd be curious for more feedback on renaming it.
The main advantage of "Direct message" as a term is it's more clear than "Private message" about the distinction between it and e.g. "Messages to private streams".

We would likely have details like the private message type staying around in the API for backwards-compatibility for years after changing what we call it in the UI, but I don't see technical concerns as a material issue around naming here.
So, in light of recent conversations in #design > align our terminology, I'm going to bump this topic and ask for opinions once more.
I think if we rename Stream to Channel we can just as well rename PM to DM. I added it to the #15753 description.
@Gittenburg I think it's worth leaving the thread/topic distinction in there, but in terms of features? Would a table work?
Do you mean reformatting the list as a table?
The "private" => "direct" rename idea is likely much less expensive to do completely than stream=>channel. So might be worth doing as a warmup project if we think we want to do both.
Bumping this conversation after seeing #user community > comic strip.

Tim Abbott said:

I think that's a good conversation to have a couple weeks after we release 5.0; discussing this kind of major change is mainly a distraction right now.

@Alya Abbott / @Vlad Korobov, do you have thoughts?
(there was a bit of conversation at #user community > comic strip stream -> channel which is tangentially related , so maybe skimming through there might be useful.)

Hm, I don't know if this is the right dataset, but it's not clear that DM is necessarily the dominant term? https://trends.google.com/trends/explore?date=all&q=private%20message,direct%20message

Screen-Shot-2022-04-14-at-9.07.37-PM.png

The "related queries" section is super interesting there, makes it seem like instagram popularized "direct message" and facebook popularized "private message"... looking at facebooks UI they don't really say "private message" anywhere, but maybe they did in the past, I don't know.

The search terms in https://trends.google.com/trends/explore?date=2017-03-15%202022-04-15&q=private%20message,direct%20message seem more interesting, there's mention of teams and gmail for private and discord and instagram for direct. (I wonder why there's such a spike march 2020... that's initial pandemic era...)
I just mean to say pulling the date range closer makes it more interesting and perhaps more relevant, but I don't really know.
I pretty strongly prefer PM to DM.
I heard DM before learned about PM in Zulip. I think at this point there is no reason to change. P stands for personal and for private.

Steve Howell (showell) said:

I pretty strongly prefer PM to DM.

Yeah, I do too in terms of my personal preference, though I'm not sure that alone is actually an important consideration. I guess one data point is that I haven't seen folks using the word "Direct message" to refer to private messages in Zulip, which would be the case if the term were strongly fixed in people's minds.
(In contrast, folks say "channel" when they mean "stream" decently often).

Just want to raise that again. Just because I realized that we have 3 types of streams:

  • private stream
  • regular stream
  • public/global stream

So the word public/private is already used in relation to a stream.
It would be great to have direct messages different in some way.
Messages or conversations isn't different, because a user can message to a stream/topic.

And I think that idea of the message to a particular person isn't privacy of conversation but directness.
When I message to a topic is not direct but it could be private. When I message to selected by me people it is more about directness than privacy.

I certainly agree that it would make our documentation/terminology a bit easier if we moved away from the term "private messages" in favor of "direct messages". That may not necessarily justify a change, but it is a consideration.
I find the two arguments Vlad Korobov made above more convincing than the previous discussion.
So the idea of rebranding from "private message" to "direct message" came up again in #design > UI redesign: compose box, and I'd like to register that I'm in favor of doing such a change.

For looking at what would be involved:

  • If we're OK with changing nothing about the API or data model (i.e. just change user-facing strings, and worry about changing internals later), there's only about 50 translated strings that contain "private message" in them in the Zulip server and web application that would need to change.
  • There's a bit of a transition messyness if we rebrand this and don't simultaneously do a self-hosted server release and mobile app release, in that it'll be hard to run a self-hosted Zulip installation with consistent terminology around this.
  • There's probably a lot of work on the Help Center etc. after a rename, but it's probably not hard.
I don't even think that absolute synchronization of change is critical. I don't even think that people will notice the change :smile:
If they are using the app in a language other than English, there will be some highly visible strings that will show up in English all of a sudden, so I guess that will be noticeable. :)
Yeah. And we should just keep in mind we might have a few months between when different systems transition if we don't put effort into coordination of such a change.

Hm, so at this point in the discussion, it seems like we do want to make this transition. However, it's not clear to me that this is a priority -- are there reasons to push on this now rather than later?

Doing this sort of change if we've decided to do it has two significant benefits:

  • While having design conversations, we can use the new terminology. There may be places where something looks better/worse with the slightly different string lengths, for example.
  • When doing new feature work, we can use the new names (for example, today, I thought about a name for a file that is private_message_x that we'd probably want to call direct_message_x if we were migrating).
  • We can start figuring out how to do the API migration, which is the kind of thing that might take like a year of staged transitions to complete for backwards-compatibility reasons ("subject" still exists in a couple places in our API, and we renamed "subject" to "topic" in the UI like 8 years ago!). The first step or two of that sort of staged migration might be a small amount of work, followed by a lot of waiting.
Makes sense. I'd be fine with kicking this off (not sure what the first steps are), just want to make sure it doesn't distract too much from high-priority initiatives.

I think the first step is for someone on the core team to do a PR changing all the translateable strings containing "private message" as noted here:

https://chat.zulip.org/#narrow/stream/101-design/topic/.22Private.22.20vs.20.22Direct.22/near/1486226

We can then test-deploy that and see how it feels / catch anything we missed.
Assuming we get that working, and we like the outcome, we'd need to schedule a project to fix the Help Center, and maybe merge those two changes together to have a complete transition of the UI?
And then we can open a bunch of follow-up issues for various internals changes.

Tim Abbott said:

Assuming we get that working, and we like the outcome, we'd need to schedule a project to fix the Help Center, and maybe merge those two changes together to have a complete transition of the UI?

Also at this step, we'll want to make a similar change on mobile.

Tim Abbott said:

I think the first step is for someone on the core team to do a PR changing all the translateable strings containing "private message" as noted here:

https://chat.zulip.org/#narrow/stream/101-design/topic/.22Private.22.20vs.20.22Direct.22/near/1486226

We can then test-deploy that and see how it feels / catch anything we missed.

@Lauryn Menard Would you be up for adding this to your list?
Sure :thumbs_up:
Quick question/confirmation - we want "group private messages" to be "group direct messages" then?

Current - group private messages - empty narrow banner

Updated - group direct messages - empty narrow banner
I think that's probably the best option, yeah.
Also, I'm going to switch instances of "PMs" in translated strings to be "DMs". A very visible instance of that is in the Recent Conversations filters.
I think in translations if PM was translated as personal messages instead of private that would be ok… it is like this in Russian: личные сообщения / личка

To follow up on this from a ZT perspective, this can be a straightforward change for our next release, though presumably it would be good to not do a client release with the name until approximately when the server has it? Though cloud may before that?
(similarly for mobile I suppose)
(filed #T1288)

I think assuming folks continue to not complain about anything in the strings migration, we'll want to draft the documentation updates to go along with this change, and then merge those alongside the UI update. I think after that point, we'd be happy for the mobile and terminal apps to update their strings.

I think from a technical perspective, the change is something we could absolutely backport to the 6.x branch; the main issue with that will be translation coverage. So one theory for the release plan would be:

  • We try to merge this PR to main and the 6.x branch this week.
  • We immediately upload the updated strings for translators and post a request for them to translate these strings over the next couple weeks.
  • We potentially keep the commits reverted for Zulip Cloud pending client work.
  • We plan to do a 6.x maintenance release late this month, with "We renamed private message => direct message to match main and the mobile apps" as an important part of the release notes.
  • We do mobile/terminal releases aimed to be more or less simultaneous with the strings update.
  • Any API changes to name things more nicely for "direct messages" being what it's called would be for the main branch.

Thoughts?
@Tim Abbott If we are indeed aiming to merge this week, let's make the call ASAP, so that there's time to make the documentation changes. (@David Rosa FYI)

@Greg Price @Chris Bobbe can I get your attention on the above transition plan for mobile?

And @Alex Vandiver can I get your thoughts on whether you'd feel comfortable with our doing "we renamed private messages" as a backport? The other option is that Zulip Cloud and the mobile apps agree on "direct messages" but self-hosted installations have the old strings until we do a release 7.0, which I think is not the end of the world, but might make us feel like we should delay merging this until later in the release cycle.

I don't feel like it's a great backport.

But I also don't feel like it's the sort of thing that people will notice if they're comparing Zulip Cloud to their own deploy, so I don't think that there's a strong reason to hold off on merging it.
Well it certainly makes our lives easier to not try backporting it. The string change itself would backport easily, but the Help Center updates to go with it might not.

I am somewhat of the opinion that probably nobody will actually find it confusing at all to have a mismatch between the mobile/terminal apps and your self-hosted server... especially in this direction, because the mobile apps mostly use icons to indicate "private messages" in the main screens anyway; I think it's just the "New PM" and "New group PM" button strings...

I think these are the places where "private message" or "pm" appears in the UI (excluding things that should only show if there's a programmer error, like the RootErrorBoundary):

  • The label on the "people" icon in the bottom tab bar (shown to screen readers and iPads)
  • On the user profile screen, in a button to go to the 1:1 PM narrow for the user
  • As a button in the (Android-only) share-to-Zulip flow
  • In the "Mark messages as read on scroll" setting screen, in the subtitle for the "Only in conversation views" option, which is currently "Messages will be automatically marked as read only when viewing a single topic or private message conversation.".

Yeah, none of those seem important. So I think let's go with a revised plan where we merge this change to main and be comfortable with taht being pushed to Zulip Cloud as soon as we can have /help/ documentation updates ready, don't backport it to 6.x, and update the mobile and terminal app strings when convenient.
So @David Rosa you can start working on the /help/ updates for this. I think I won't block merging to main and uploading translations on that happening.

I think these are the places where "private message" or "pm" appears in the UI

Er, and these, which were in my head at the time but it looks like I forgot to write them down:

  • The "New PM" and "New group PM" buttons in PmConversationsScreen, which is the tab with the people icon.
(I don't expect that to change the conclusion; sorry if it does. :smile:)

Tim Abbott said:

So David Rosa you can start working on the /help/ updates for this. I think I won't block merging to main and uploading translations on that happening.

WIP #24337.
As discussed, I've merged #24224 as we've gotten no reports of issues with it. #24337 looks like it isn't quite finished; @David Rosa can you prioritize that work?
Rebased/updated #24337.

Thanks! Posted a few review comments. I think the only detail that seems worth bringing up here is keyboard shortcuts. Right now, we have:

  • p to go the first unread private message conversation
  • P to jump to all private messages
  • d to open drafts

The first two key choices will be significantly less intuitive following this change. I'm not sure it's actually a problem to leave things as is, but I wanted to flag it as a potentially interesting design question.

So the documentation updates in #24337 are merged. There's basically two vestiges of "private messages" remaining in the web app UI:

  • They keyboard shortcuts p and P. Given that d is already take by drafts, and that seems pretty intuitive, my current opinion is we should take no action here.
  • The search operators pm-with: and group-pm-with (https://zulip.com/help/search-for-messages#search-by-location).

For the search operators, I think it's worth having a conversation about what we want to change them to, since I think s/pm/dm/ is not the optional adjustment.

Now, these operators appear in the UI today via the top search box, but our plans for search involve users mostly just seeing fancier pills, so this decision probably has more long-term impact on the API. But I think it's still worth thinking about from a design perspective regardless.

The pm-with:1,3,4 operator filters to the direct message conversation containing that exact set of users. And group-pm-with:1 filters to all direct message conversations that include that user (and possibly others!). You use multiple copies of group-pm-with to ask for multiple users.

(We support multiple encodings of users (email addresses and user IDs), but that's not really important for this discussion.).

My proposal is that we rename these to just dm:1,3,4 and dm-including:1 -- I think the with feels unnecessary in the first one, and -including seems a bit clearer to me than something like group-dm-with.

Thoughts?
We'd need to support the old operator formats in the API for backwards-compatibility, of course; we'll work out the details of that in #api design once we've settled on what we want to migrate to.

Tim Abbott said:

And group-pm-with:1 filters to all direct message conversations that include that user (and possibly others!).

I think that's not quite accurate -- it does not include 1:1 DM conversations with that users.
Changing the keywords to dm and dm-including, along with updating the logic for dm-including to be what Tim Abbott thought it already is, could be reasonable.

Alya Abbott said:

Changing the keywords to dm and dm-including, along with updating the logic for dm-including to be what Tim Abbott thought it already is, could be reasonable.

I like that plan.

I guess it would be less helpful in the situation when you remember that something was a group DM (not a 1:1 DM) with person X, but can't specifically recall any other participants in the conversation. But that's probably rare enough to be fine, and the definition seems simpler than what we are currently using.

Having dm-including seems a good clarification of the current behavior, or at least a useful extension of it.

I'm in favor of dm due to how concise it could be, though I would be slightly concerned that it's too terse; dm-with is arguably clearer if we kept that, and should be distinct from dm-including in that case?

Re specifically group DMs, one alternative if we kept it, would be to support it as dm-group[-with], since keeping the same prefix would be useful?

In terms of the last point, other than a rarity point of view, could one build combinations of different queries using the syntax we have or slight extensions? eg. if we added is:dm-group or similar (as opposed to current is:private? will that be is:direct?)

My only other thoughts on this are that we miss out on the plural form if we otherwise talk about DMs but use dm, though dms is not that great either. The other side of the coin is that we don't use 'message' everywhere else, so we could use direct instead.
Oh yeah, is:private should probably change to is:direct.
We could add to our search /help/ article examples some version of "dm-including:1 -dm:1" to get "Just group DMs including user 1".

Alya Abbott said:

Oh yeah, is:private should probably change to is:direct.

is:dm might feel more intuitive? Maybe this is an incorrect intuition, but I feel like in other products, "DM" is used a lot more than "Direct messages", which biases me more towards the abbreviation spelling of it.

I don't like dm-with because it actually sounds like it's the same thing as dm-including... we thought about changing it when we introduced group-pm-with, but didn't muster the activation energy to do so at the time.

Hey, I recently came across the zulip-terminal project. I went through the issue linked to this discussion and as far as I understood, We have to rename Private Messages to Direct Messages and PM to DM. Please correct me if I'm wrong.
Correct but #zulip-terminal is a better place for that discussion @Chandan Gowda.
Okay. Thanks @Tim Abbott
I filed Update and improve direct message search filters #24806 with my best understanding of what we landed on.
For the "dm-including", if the user uses this operator with themself (e.g. if I did dm-including:Lauryn Menard) would the messages matched/fetched be the same as is:private?
Because "dm-including" will be for all direct 1-on-1 conversations and direct group conversations with that user.
I think so, yeah.

For the new "dm-including" operator, when there are no direct messages with the person (one-on-one or group), what do we want the empty banners to say? Both for the current user (note that most users will have a direct message from the Welcome bot and will never see this) and for another user.

My initial idea for the current user was: "You don't have any direct message conversations yet! Why not start a conversation with someone?"

And for another user was: "You have no direct messages including {person} yet. Why not start the conversation?"
Current user has no direct message conversations at all
Current user has no direct message conversations with user X
That proposal sounds reasonable to me.

I think that sounds generally good; for this one:

"You don't have any direct message conversations yet! Why not start a conversation with someone?"

I'd consider dropping this second sentence; it feels like an extra string for translators that mostly won't actually be useful?
Perhaps also drop the exclamation point. Especially without the second sentence, it feels more hectoring or critical than helpful.
Thanks for the clear feedback!
I've got all of that up in the WIP for these changes, #25003.

Just as a quick note for the current status of this draft PR, it's got the implementations for is:dm, dm:... and dm-including:... done. Still to-do is the deprecation of group-pm-with in the web app and the documentation updates.

It would be good for me to get clarity here on what we want to do for group-pm-with.

  • Do we want to support any search pills / suggestions for group-pm-with?
  • Do we want group-pm-with:user_X to return the narrow/URL equivalent to dm-including:user_X, -dm:user_X, which should be the equivalent?

Here are some example screenshots from the dev environment with a simple example:
group-pm-with for user-24, dm-including with negated dm for same user-24, dm-including for user-24

Do we want to support any search pills / suggestions for group-pm-with?

I was thinking not.

• Do we want group-pm-with:user_X to return the narrow/URL equivalent to dm-including:user_X, -dm:user_X, which should be the equivalent?

I don't have strong feeling on this one. If we don't support it in the suggestions, then someone would need to manually type it out (based on being familiar with it from past use, I guess).

I think it's likely that few users are familiar with group-pm-with, and those who know about it use it rarely, and those that do know about it will likely know how to navigate our search help, so I don't think there's any need for special logic of that form; we should just do something easy on that detail, which is probably translating it to the similar dm-including query. If it's equally easy, maybe the dm-including + -dm version is more precise, but I don't think it's worth much time/attention.
(For context, group-pm-with is used <1000x as often as keyword search or searching by sender).

Okay. I've updated #25003 for the easier version of translating group-pm-with (if someone has a saved search link/URL or has a strong muscle memory of that search operator) to show the dm-including results for now.
